Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search News/Activism Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson Last week, social media group Meta exemplified all the developments at once. It dropped its content moderation policies, added longtime Trump friend and Ultimate Fighting Championship chief executive Dana White to its board, shifted its chief diversity officer to a new role, and dropped its goals to boost racial and gender diversity among its managers and suppliers. Founder Mark Zuckerberg later joined a podcast hosted by Joe Rogan, who backed Trump in the election, and lamented the rise of ‚Äúculturally neutered‚Äù companies. ‚ÄúI think having a culture that celebrates the aggression a bit more has its own merits that are really positive,‚Äù Zuckerberg said. Liberal politicians and investor activists are appalled. ‚ÄúCorporate caving to Trump is deeply distressing,‚Äù said Brad Lander, New York City comptroller and an advocate for sustainable investing. ‚ÄúWe have seen too many examples through history. That, over time, is how democracy and fundamental rights are weakened.‚Äù But companies, executives and analysts contend that the motives driving the changes are complex and reflect far more than a desire to pander to the incoming president. The mood among their customers has changed, executives argue, and court rulings and state and federal regulatory probes, notably last year‚Äôs US Supreme Court ruling outlawing affirmative action in colleges, have undercut the footing of diversity and climate programmes. For many, the new administration offers a welcome opportunity to roll back some of the tighter rules enacted during President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration and bend tax and regulatory policy in their favour. David Solomon, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, recently praised the incoming Trump administration for ‚Äúrunning a growth-y playbook‚Äù. ‚ÄúI am quite optimistic that this administration is going to run a very, very pro-growth agenda,‚Äù Solomon said at a Reuters event. Tech leaders have made some of the highest-profile gestures towards Trump and conservative values in a pre-emptive effort to mend fences. Apple‚Äôs Tim Cook, Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai and OpenAI‚Äôs Sam Altman all joined Meta‚Äôs Zuckerberg and Amazon‚Äôs Bezos in pledging $1mn to Trump‚Äôs inauguration fund, and Pichai also flew to Mar-a-Lago. Trump previously claimed Google was ‚Äúrigged‚Äù to hide positive coverage about him. ‚ÄúIt is a statement of the lack of confidence and backbone of tech executives,‚Äù said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, senior associate dean for leadership studies at the Yale School of Management. He described their contributions to Trump‚Äôs inauguration as a ‚Äútithing scheme‚Äù to the president-elect. In the financial sector, the most visible shift since Trump‚Äôs election has been around climate change. All the major Wall Street banks and several big money managers have quit industry groups that seek to use their financial clout to cut carbon emissions. BlackRock, the target of conservative state probes and lawsuits over its prior support for sustainable investing, explicitly cited legal and regulatory issues for its departure from the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative last week. Even the way people on Wall Street talk and interact is changing. Bankers and financiers say Trump‚Äôs victory has emboldened those who chafed at ‚Äúwoke doctrine‚Äù and felt they had to self-censor or change their language to avoid offending younger colleagues, women, minorities or disabled people. ‚ÄúI feel liberated,‚Äù said a top banker. ‚ÄúWe can say ‚Äòretard‚Äô and ‚Äòpus*y‚Äô without the fear of getting cancelled . . . it‚Äôs a new dawn.‚Äù Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search News/Activism Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson Founder Mark Zuckerberg later joined a podcast hosted by Joe Rogan, who backed Trump in the election, and lamented the rise of ‚Äúculturally neutered‚Äù companies. ‚ÄúI think having a culture that celebrates the aggression a bit more has its own merits that are really positive,‚Äù Zuckerberg said. Liberal politicians and investor activists are appalled. ‚ÄúCorporate caving to Trump is deeply distressing,‚Äù said Brad Lander, New York City comptroller and an advocate for sustainable investing. ‚ÄúWe have seen too many examples through history. That, over time, is how democracy and fundamental rights are weakened.‚Äù But companies, executives and analysts contend that the motives driving the changes are complex and reflect far more than a desire to pander to the incoming president. The mood among their customers has changed, executives argue, and court rulings and state and federal regulatory probes, notably last year‚Äôs US Supreme Court ruling outlawing affirmative action in colleges, have undercut the footing of diversity and climate programmes. For many, the new administration offers a welcome opportunity to roll back some of the tighter rules enacted during President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration and bend tax and regulatory policy in their favour. David Solomon, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, recently praised the incoming Trump administration for ‚Äúrunning a growth-y playbook‚Äù. ‚ÄúI am quite optimistic that this administration is going to run a very, very pro-growth agenda,‚Äù Solomon said at a Reuters event. Tech leaders have made some of the highest-profile gestures towards Trump and conservative values in a pre-emptive effort to mend fences. Apple‚Äôs Tim Cook, Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai and OpenAI‚Äôs Sam Altman all joined Meta‚Äôs Zuckerberg and Amazon‚Äôs Bezos in pledging $1mn to Trump‚Äôs inauguration fund, and Pichai also flew to Mar-a-Lago. Trump previously claimed Google was ‚Äúrigged‚Äù to hide positive coverage about him. ‚ÄúIt is a statement of the lack of confidence and backbone of tech executives,‚Äù said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, senior associate dean for leadership studies at the Yale School of Management. He described their contributions to Trump‚Äôs inauguration as a ‚Äútithing scheme‚Äù to the president-elect. In the financial sector, the most visible shift since Trump‚Äôs election has been around climate change. All the major Wall Street banks and several big money managers have quit industry groups that seek to use their financial clout to cut carbon emissions. BlackRock, the target of conservative state probes and lawsuits over its prior support for sustainable investing, explicitly cited legal and regulatory issues for its departure from the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative last week. Even the way people on Wall Street talk and interact is changing. Bankers and financiers say Trump‚Äôs victory has emboldened those who chafed at ‚Äúwoke doctrine‚Äù and felt they had to self-censor or change their language to avoid offending younger colleagues, women, minorities or disabled people. ‚ÄúI feel liberated,‚Äù said a top banker. ‚ÄúWe can say ‚Äòretard‚Äô and ‚Äòpus*y‚Äô without the fear of getting cancelled . . . it‚Äôs a new dawn.‚Äù Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search News/Activism Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson Liberal politicians and investor activists are appalled. ‚ÄúCorporate caving to Trump is deeply distressing,‚Äù said Brad Lander, New York City comptroller and an advocate for sustainable investing. ‚ÄúWe have seen too many examples through history. That, over time, is how democracy and fundamental rights are weakened.‚Äù But companies, executives and analysts contend that the motives driving the changes are complex and reflect far more than a desire to pander to the incoming president. The mood among their customers has changed, executives argue, and court rulings and state and federal regulatory probes, notably last year‚Äôs US Supreme Court ruling outlawing affirmative action in colleges, have undercut the footing of diversity and climate programmes. For many, the new administration offers a welcome opportunity to roll back some of the tighter rules enacted during President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration and bend tax and regulatory policy in their favour. David Solomon, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, recently praised the incoming Trump administration for ‚Äúrunning a growth-y playbook‚Äù. ‚ÄúI am quite optimistic that this administration is going to run a very, very pro-growth agenda,‚Äù Solomon said at a Reuters event. Tech leaders have made some of the highest-profile gestures towards Trump and conservative values in a pre-emptive effort to mend fences. Apple‚Äôs Tim Cook, Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai and OpenAI‚Äôs Sam Altman all joined Meta‚Äôs Zuckerberg and Amazon‚Äôs Bezos in pledging $1mn to Trump‚Äôs inauguration fund, and Pichai also flew to Mar-a-Lago. Trump previously claimed Google was ‚Äúrigged‚Äù to hide positive coverage about him. ‚ÄúIt is a statement of the lack of confidence and backbone of tech executives,‚Äù said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, senior associate dean for leadership studies at the Yale School of Management. He described their contributions to Trump‚Äôs inauguration as a ‚Äútithing scheme‚Äù to the president-elect. In the financial sector, the most visible shift since Trump‚Äôs election has been around climate change. All the major Wall Street banks and several big money managers have quit industry groups that seek to use their financial clout to cut carbon emissions. BlackRock, the target of conservative state probes and lawsuits over its prior support for sustainable investing, explicitly cited legal and regulatory issues for its departure from the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative last week. Even the way people on Wall Street talk and interact is changing. Bankers and financiers say Trump‚Äôs victory has emboldened those who chafed at ‚Äúwoke doctrine‚Äù and felt they had to self-censor or change their language to avoid offending younger colleagues, women, minorities or disabled people. ‚ÄúI feel liberated,‚Äù said a top banker. ‚ÄúWe can say ‚Äòretard‚Äô and ‚Äòpus*y‚Äô without the fear of getting cancelled . . . it‚Äôs a new dawn.‚Äù Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search News/Activism Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson But companies, executives and analysts contend that the motives driving the changes are complex and reflect far more than a desire to pander to the incoming president. The mood among their customers has changed, executives argue, and court rulings and state and federal regulatory probes, notably last year‚Äôs US Supreme Court ruling outlawing affirmative action in colleges, have undercut the footing of diversity and climate programmes. For many, the new administration offers a welcome opportunity to roll back some of the tighter rules enacted during President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration and bend tax and regulatory policy in their favour. David Solomon, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, recently praised the incoming Trump administration for ‚Äúrunning a growth-y playbook‚Äù. ‚ÄúI am quite optimistic that this administration is going to run a very, very pro-growth agenda,‚Äù Solomon said at a Reuters event. Tech leaders have made some of the highest-profile gestures towards Trump and conservative values in a pre-emptive effort to mend fences. Apple‚Äôs Tim Cook, Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai and OpenAI‚Äôs Sam Altman all joined Meta‚Äôs Zuckerberg and Amazon‚Äôs Bezos in pledging $1mn to Trump‚Äôs inauguration fund, and Pichai also flew to Mar-a-Lago. Trump previously claimed Google was ‚Äúrigged‚Äù to hide positive coverage about him. ‚ÄúIt is a statement of the lack of confidence and backbone of tech executives,‚Äù said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, senior associate dean for leadership studies at the Yale School of Management. He described their contributions to Trump‚Äôs inauguration as a ‚Äútithing scheme‚Äù to the president-elect. In the financial sector, the most visible shift since Trump‚Äôs election has been around climate change. All the major Wall Street banks and several big money managers have quit industry groups that seek to use their financial clout to cut carbon emissions. BlackRock, the target of conservative state probes and lawsuits over its prior support for sustainable investing, explicitly cited legal and regulatory issues for its departure from the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative last week. Even the way people on Wall Street talk and interact is changing. Bankers and financiers say Trump‚Äôs victory has emboldened those who chafed at ‚Äúwoke doctrine‚Äù and felt they had to self-censor or change their language to avoid offending younger colleagues, women, minorities or disabled people. ‚ÄúI feel liberated,‚Äù said a top banker. ‚ÄúWe can say ‚Äòretard‚Äô and ‚Äòpus*y‚Äô without the fear of getting cancelled . . . it‚Äôs a new dawn.‚Äù Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search News/Activism Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson The mood among their customers has changed, executives argue, and court rulings and state and federal regulatory probes, notably last year‚Äôs US Supreme Court ruling outlawing affirmative action in colleges, have undercut the footing of diversity and climate programmes. For many, the new administration offers a welcome opportunity to roll back some of the tighter rules enacted during President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration and bend tax and regulatory policy in their favour. David Solomon, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, recently praised the incoming Trump administration for ‚Äúrunning a growth-y playbook‚Äù. ‚ÄúI am quite optimistic that this administration is going to run a very, very pro-growth agenda,‚Äù Solomon said at a Reuters event. Tech leaders have made some of the highest-profile gestures towards Trump and conservative values in a pre-emptive effort to mend fences. Apple‚Äôs Tim Cook, Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai and OpenAI‚Äôs Sam Altman all joined Meta‚Äôs Zuckerberg and Amazon‚Äôs Bezos in pledging $1mn to Trump‚Äôs inauguration fund, and Pichai also flew to Mar-a-Lago. Trump previously claimed Google was ‚Äúrigged‚Äù to hide positive coverage about him. ‚ÄúIt is a statement of the lack of confidence and backbone of tech executives,‚Äù said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, senior associate dean for leadership studies at the Yale School of Management. He described their contributions to Trump‚Äôs inauguration as a ‚Äútithing scheme‚Äù to the president-elect. In the financial sector, the most visible shift since Trump‚Äôs election has been around climate change. All the major Wall Street banks and several big money managers have quit industry groups that seek to use their financial clout to cut carbon emissions. BlackRock, the target of conservative state probes and lawsuits over its prior support for sustainable investing, explicitly cited legal and regulatory issues for its departure from the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative last week. Even the way people on Wall Street talk and interact is changing. Bankers and financiers say Trump‚Äôs victory has emboldened those who chafed at ‚Äúwoke doctrine‚Äù and felt they had to self-censor or change their language to avoid offending younger colleagues, women, minorities or disabled people. ‚ÄúI feel liberated,‚Äù said a top banker. ‚ÄúWe can say ‚Äòretard‚Äô and ‚Äòpus*y‚Äô without the fear of getting cancelled . . . it‚Äôs a new dawn.‚Äù Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search News/Activism Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson For many, the new administration offers a welcome opportunity to roll back some of the tighter rules enacted during President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration and bend tax and regulatory policy in their favour. David Solomon, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, recently praised the incoming Trump administration for ‚Äúrunning a growth-y playbook‚Äù. ‚ÄúI am quite optimistic that this administration is going to run a very, very pro-growth agenda,‚Äù Solomon said at a Reuters event. Tech leaders have made some of the highest-profile gestures towards Trump and conservative values in a pre-emptive effort to mend fences. Apple‚Äôs Tim Cook, Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai and OpenAI‚Äôs Sam Altman all joined Meta‚Äôs Zuckerberg and Amazon‚Äôs Bezos in pledging $1mn to Trump‚Äôs inauguration fund, and Pichai also flew to Mar-a-Lago. Trump previously claimed Google was ‚Äúrigged‚Äù to hide positive coverage about him. ‚ÄúIt is a statement of the lack of confidence and backbone of tech executives,‚Äù said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, senior associate dean for leadership studies at the Yale School of Management. He described their contributions to Trump‚Äôs inauguration as a ‚Äútithing scheme‚Äù to the president-elect. In the financial sector, the most visible shift since Trump‚Äôs election has been around climate change. All the major Wall Street banks and several big money managers have quit industry groups that seek to use their financial clout to cut carbon emissions. BlackRock, the target of conservative state probes and lawsuits over its prior support for sustainable investing, explicitly cited legal and regulatory issues for its departure from the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative last week. Even the way people on Wall Street talk and interact is changing. Bankers and financiers say Trump‚Äôs victory has emboldened those who chafed at ‚Äúwoke doctrine‚Äù and felt they had to self-censor or change their language to avoid offending younger colleagues, women, minorities or disabled people. ‚ÄúI feel liberated,‚Äù said a top banker. ‚ÄúWe can say ‚Äòretard‚Äô and ‚Äòpus*y‚Äô without the fear of getting cancelled . . . it‚Äôs a new dawn.‚Äù Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! Tech leaders have made some of the highest-profile gestures towards Trump and conservative values in a pre-emptive effort to mend fences. Apple‚Äôs Tim Cook, Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai and OpenAI‚Äôs Sam Altman all joined Meta‚Äôs Zuckerberg and Amazon‚Äôs Bezos in pledging $1mn to Trump‚Äôs inauguration fund, and Pichai also flew to Mar-a-Lago. Trump previously claimed Google was ‚Äúrigged‚Äù to hide positive coverage about him. ‚ÄúIt is a statement of the lack of confidence and backbone of tech executives,‚Äù said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, senior associate dean for leadership studies at the Yale School of Management. He described their contributions to Trump‚Äôs inauguration as a ‚Äútithing scheme‚Äù to the president-elect. In the financial sector, the most visible shift since Trump‚Äôs election has been around climate change. All the major Wall Street banks and several big money managers have quit industry groups that seek to use their financial clout to cut carbon emissions. BlackRock, the target of conservative state probes and lawsuits over its prior support for sustainable investing, explicitly cited legal and regulatory issues for its departure from the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative last week. Even the way people on Wall Street talk and interact is changing. Bankers and financiers say Trump‚Äôs victory has emboldened those who chafed at ‚Äúwoke doctrine‚Äù and felt they had to self-censor or change their language to avoid offending younger colleagues, women, minorities or disabled people. ‚ÄúI feel liberated,‚Äù said a top banker. ‚ÄúWe can say ‚Äòretard‚Äô and ‚Äòpus*y‚Äô without the fear of getting cancelled . . . it‚Äôs a new dawn.‚Äù Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search News/Activism Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson ‚ÄúI am quite optimistic that this administration is going to run a very, very pro-growth agenda,‚Äù Solomon said at a Reuters event. Tech leaders have made some of the highest-profile gestures towards Trump and conservative values in a pre-emptive effort to mend fences. Apple‚Äôs Tim Cook, Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai and OpenAI‚Äôs Sam Altman all joined Meta‚Äôs Zuckerberg and Amazon‚Äôs Bezos in pledging $1mn to Trump‚Äôs inauguration fund, and Pichai also flew to Mar-a-Lago. Trump previously claimed Google was ‚Äúrigged‚Äù to hide positive coverage about him. ‚ÄúIt is a statement of the lack of confidence and backbone of tech executives,‚Äù said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, senior associate dean for leadership studies at the Yale School of Management. He described their contributions to Trump‚Äôs inauguration as a ‚Äútithing scheme‚Äù to the president-elect. In the financial sector, the most visible shift since Trump‚Äôs election has been around climate change. All the major Wall Street banks and several big money managers have quit industry groups that seek to use their financial clout to cut carbon emissions. BlackRock, the target of conservative state probes and lawsuits over its prior support for sustainable investing, explicitly cited legal and regulatory issues for its departure from the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative last week. Even the way people on Wall Street talk and interact is changing. Bankers and financiers say Trump‚Äôs victory has emboldened those who chafed at ‚Äúwoke doctrine‚Äù and felt they had to self-censor or change their language to avoid offending younger colleagues, women, minorities or disabled people. ‚ÄúI feel liberated,‚Äù said a top banker. ‚ÄúWe can say ‚Äòretard‚Äô and ‚Äòpus*y‚Äô without the fear of getting cancelled . . . it‚Äôs a new dawn.‚Äù Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search News/Activism Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson Tech leaders have made some of the highest-profile gestures towards Trump and conservative values in a pre-emptive effort to mend fences. Apple‚Äôs Tim Cook, Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai and OpenAI‚Äôs Sam Altman all joined Meta‚Äôs Zuckerberg and Amazon‚Äôs Bezos in pledging $1mn to Trump‚Äôs inauguration fund, and Pichai also flew to Mar-a-Lago. Trump previously claimed Google was ‚Äúrigged‚Äù to hide positive coverage about him. ‚ÄúIt is a statement of the lack of confidence and backbone of tech executives,‚Äù said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, senior associate dean for leadership studies at the Yale School of Management. He described their contributions to Trump‚Äôs inauguration as a ‚Äútithing scheme‚Äù to the president-elect. In the financial sector, the most visible shift since Trump‚Äôs election has been around climate change. All the major Wall Street banks and several big money managers have quit industry groups that seek to use their financial clout to cut carbon emissions. BlackRock, the target of conservative state probes and lawsuits over its prior support for sustainable investing, explicitly cited legal and regulatory issues for its departure from the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative last week. Even the way people on Wall Street talk and interact is changing. Bankers and financiers say Trump‚Äôs victory has emboldened those who chafed at ‚Äúwoke doctrine‚Äù and felt they had to self-censor or change their language to avoid offending younger colleagues, women, minorities or disabled people. ‚ÄúI feel liberated,‚Äù said a top banker. ‚ÄúWe can say ‚Äòretard‚Äô and ‚Äòpus*y‚Äô without the fear of getting cancelled . . . it‚Äôs a new dawn.‚Äù Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search News/Activism Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson ‚ÄúIt is a statement of the lack of confidence and backbone of tech executives,‚Äù said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, senior associate dean for leadership studies at the Yale School of Management. He described their contributions to Trump‚Äôs inauguration as a ‚Äútithing scheme‚Äù to the president-elect. In the financial sector, the most visible shift since Trump‚Äôs election has been around climate change. All the major Wall Street banks and several big money managers have quit industry groups that seek to use their financial clout to cut carbon emissions. BlackRock, the target of conservative state probes and lawsuits over its prior support for sustainable investing, explicitly cited legal and regulatory issues for its departure from the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative last week. Even the way people on Wall Street talk and interact is changing. Bankers and financiers say Trump‚Äôs victory has emboldened those who chafed at ‚Äúwoke doctrine‚Äù and felt they had to self-censor or change their language to avoid offending younger colleagues, women, minorities or disabled people. ‚ÄúI feel liberated,‚Äù said a top banker. ‚ÄúWe can say ‚Äòretard‚Äô and ‚Äòpus*y‚Äô without the fear of getting cancelled . . . it‚Äôs a new dawn.‚Äù Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! BlackRock, the target of conservative state probes and lawsuits over its prior support for sustainable investing, explicitly cited legal and regulatory issues for its departure from the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative last week. Even the way people on Wall Street talk and interact is changing. Bankers and financiers say Trump‚Äôs victory has emboldened those who chafed at ‚Äúwoke doctrine‚Äù and felt they had to self-censor or change their language to avoid offending younger colleagues, women, minorities or disabled people. ‚ÄúI feel liberated,‚Äù said a top banker. ‚ÄúWe can say ‚Äòretard‚Äô and ‚Äòpus*y‚Äô without the fear of getting cancelled . . . it‚Äôs a new dawn.‚Äù Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search News/Activism Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson BlackRock, the target of conservative state probes and lawsuits over its prior support for sustainable investing, explicitly cited legal and regulatory issues for its departure from the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative last week. Even the way people on Wall Street talk and interact is changing. Bankers and financiers say Trump‚Äôs victory has emboldened those who chafed at ‚Äúwoke doctrine‚Äù and felt they had to self-censor or change their language to avoid offending younger colleagues, women, minorities or disabled people. ‚ÄúI feel liberated,‚Äù said a top banker. ‚ÄúWe can say ‚Äòretard‚Äô and ‚Äòpus*y‚Äô without the fear of getting cancelled . . . it‚Äôs a new dawn.‚Äù Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search News/Activism Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson Some Wall Streeters also feel able to embrace making money openly, without nodding to any broader social goals. ‚ÄúMost of us don‚Äôt have to kiss ass because, like Trump, we love America and capitalism,‚Äù one said. Consumer-facing groups, meanwhile, have become increasingly careful to avoid seeming ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, less they trigger the kind of boycotts faced by Target and Bud Light over marketing that celebrated gay and transgender people. That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey! That backlash was under way well before the election. But the shift to the right has been so rapid that some groups have been caught out. After the recent New Orleans terrorist attack, the chief executive of insurance group Allstate, Tom Wilson, drew a firestorm of criticism for saying ‚Äúwe need to be stronger together by overcoming an addiction to divisiveness and negativity‚Äù. Conservative activists accused Wilson, whose company was sponsoring a high-profile American football game in the city, of minimising murder while pushing progressive causes. Allstate tried to explain that the statement ‚Äúreflects a broader commitment to fostering trust and positivity in communities across the nation‚Äù. The other big corporate shift has been on DEI efforts, particularly since the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling against the use of race-based college admissions in June 2023. Companies including Harley-Davidson, Ford and Molson Coors began rolling back their corporate diversity in the months after the decision, and the trickle became a flood after Trump‚Äôs election victory. Walmart stopped considering race and gender in granting supplier contracts, ended racial equity training for staff, and will not renew funding for the Center for Racial Equity, which it set up with a $100mn pledge after the Floyd protests. McDonald‚Äôs last week dropped percentage goals for women and non-white managers, ceased asking suppliers to sign a DEI pledge and said it would now refer to its diversity team as a Global Inclusion Team. Both companies pointed to legal issues but also changing circumstances. McDonald‚Äôs cited ‚Äúan evolving landscape‚Äù, while saying it was committed to inclusion. Walmart said its shifting approach showed ‚Äúwe are willing to change alongside our associates and customers who represent all of America. We‚Äôve been on a journey and know we aren‚Äôt perfect, but every decision comes from a place of wanting to foster a sense of belonging.‚Äù Consultants and other corporate advisers said the shifting landscape had also given companies a way to rethink or scrap environmental and diversity goals that they were not meeting anyway. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be caught out promising and not delivering,‚Äù said Richard Edelman, who counsels corporate leaders as chief executive of Edelman, a public relations group. ‚ÄúCompanies are still committed to diversity and they‚Äôre committed to inclusion, they just don‚Äôt want to guarantee outcomes.‚Äù It is not clear whether the conservative turn will last any longer than the progressive positions companies put forward in 2020. Bryant, the former DEI executive who is now the chief executive of consulting firm Pathfinder, said many of the policy reversals seemed to be aimed at alleviating political scrutiny rather than substantive policy changes. ‚ÄúMaya Angelou said, ‚ÄòWhen people show you who they are, believe them.‚Äô When companies show you who they are, believe them as well,‚Äù she said TOPICS: Business/Economy; Culture/Society; News/Current Events KEYWORDS: corporations; maga; wokism Hey!
